results.title: Monty Python's life of Brian [DVD]
results.creator_credit: HandMade Films, John Goldstone and Terry Jones
results.brief_description: Iconic comedy from the Monty Python team, “The Life of Brian” ridicules Christianity, organised religion, politics, underground subversives and Jesus Christ. From birth, the unfortunate and guileless Brian is mistaken for the Son of God and dogged by his nearby presence as well as being pestered by his shrewish mother. The Monty Python crew each play numerous roles within the film, creating an anarchic madcap spoof of Biblical films and religious epics. With several musical interludes, including “Always look on the bright side of life” (sung at the crucifixion) the writers slay many sacred cows in the name of comedy. Blissfully sacrilegious and completely irreverent, “Life of Brian” was banned in several countries, but nevertheless garnered cult status and is regarded by many as the funniest of the Monty Python’s feature films. Also features Spike Milligan and Beatle George Harrison, whose company produced the film.

results.title: Monty
results.brief_description: Three friends, a rabbit (Tom), a duck (Doris) and a frog (Arthur) walk to school together every morning. Every morning and afternoon they wake up their snoozy, good-natured, easy-going alligator friend, Monty, to get a ride across the wide river in their way. They are somewhat ill-mannered and unappreciative of his help. One day Monty is not there, and finding they have no way to cross the river, they try 4 turtles, a catapult see-saw, balancing on Arthur. All attempts fail. “We need Monty” they cry, and Monty responds, carrying them on his back once more. Finally they appreciate, admire and thank him as bad manners are converted to good. Based on the book of the same name by James Stevenson. Suitable for children aged 4-8.

results.title: Montparnasse 19 = Modigliani of Montparnasse
results.brief_description:
Set in the bohemian quarter of Montparnasse (Paris) at the turn of the century, ‘Montparnasse 19’ follows the last days of the life of Modigliani. Thinking he is a failed painter, Modigliani has become an alcoholic. He survives thanks to the generosity of Rosalie, a restaurant owner, and his friend Zborovski. An art merchant, Morel, recognises the talent of the young painter, but prefers to wait patiently for his death in order to cash in.

Credits: Producer, Ralph Baum ; director, Jacques Becker ; writer, Henri Jeanson ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Paul Misraki ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Anouk Aimee, Gerard Sety, Lino Ventura, Lili Palmer, Lea Padovani, Lila Kedrova, Marianne Oswald, Jean Lanier.

results.title: Monterey pop
results.creator_credit: John Phillips, Lou Adler and D.A. Pennebaker
results.brief_description: In June 1967, the Mamas and the Papas hosted a three day Pop Festival in Monterey, California. D.A. Pennebaker’s outstanding film is a record of extraordinary musicians and extraordinary insight into an era. This is the 60’s in celebration, exploding with new voices and optimistic energy. Performing artists include Janis Joplin, Otis Redding, Jimi Hendrix, Jefferson Airplane, Simon and Garfunkel, Scott McKenzie, Eric Burdon and the Animals, Canned Heat and The Who.

results.title: Montana: big sky, big snow
results.brief_description: Shows many of the finest skiing locations on the state of Montana as well as beautiful shots of landscape skiing and winter-sports festivals.

results.title: Montana
results.brief_description: Morgan Lane (Errol Flynn), an Australian sheepman arrives in Fort Humbolt, Montana ready to buy some land for grazing - his determination stemming from his father being driven off the land by cattlemen. His mission seems hard to achieve, especially when the suspicious locals are not ready to accept a stranger into their midst, and a sheep rancher at that. Lane faces opposition from cattle rancher Maria Singleton (Alexis Smith), a flame haired beauty who is initially attracted to the new stranger, until she discovers his motives. Singleton has a passionate aversion to sheepmen as her father, and her fiance lost their lives in a sheep and cattle war. Cast also includes Alexis Smith, S.Z. Sakall, Douglas Kennedy, James Brown and Ian MacDonald. Based on a novel by Ernest Haycock.

results.title: Montagnes Magiques = Magic Mountains
results.brief_description:
In this film montage Robert Enrico describes the enduring fascination of men for the mountains as well as the many relationship humanity has entertained with rock formations: from rock painting to health spa; from heretic stronghold (Montsegur) to Catholic pilgrimage (Lourdes) as well as the many research and scientific usages (observatories, solar stations).

Credits: Producer, J. Jacoupy ; director, Robert Enrico ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Francois de Roubaix.

results.title: Mont Blanc: the fool killer
results.brief_description: Mont Blanc at 15,781 feet is the highest mountain in Europe and a graveyard to many reckless climbers. Frederick Burlingham, the director/photographer of this film, has scaled Mont Blanc four times. This film shows close-ups of Mont Blanc through the eyes of a telescope, focusing on some of the areas where many mountaineers have perished. Includes footage of Aiguille de Midi, a precipitous needle of 12,606 feet and a climbing party on some very tall crags. Interesting film from a historical point of view, notably the way the climbing party are dressed and how they are just roped together - very different from today’s climbers!

results.title: Monsters, Inc. [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Disney, Pixar Animation Studios, Darla Anderson and Peter Docter
results.brief_description: From the crew at Pixar (Toy story, A Bug’s life) comes “Monsters Inc.”, a story set amidst the world of monsters. The set-up is simple: at Monsters Incorporated, the staff (a delightfully bizarre looking myriad of creatures) work hard at eliciting screams from scared children, which are then bottled and used to power Monstropolis, the city where the monsters live. Sully, the top scarer at Monster’s Inc., gets into strife one night when he accidentally lets a child (a dangerous and toxic being in the monster world) over to the other side of her bedroom door. Sully and Mike (his best buddy) struggle to get Boo safely back to her bedroom, and keep her from the clutches of the CDA (Child Detection Agency). Of all the feature length films made by Pixar, this is the first to be set in a fictional world, which allows the animators a limitless palette in which to flex their imagination. The computer animation of “Monsters Inc.” is superb and the humour consistent throughout. One of the finest sequences of the film is a ride through a cavernous chamber, with Boo, Mike and Sully jumping from door to door through various countries, in search of Boo’s bedroom.
